title: Saipem 7000
text:
The Saipem 7000 is the world's third largest <a href="semi-submersible%20platform">semi-submersible</a> <a href="crane%20vessel">crane vessel</a>, after the and the . It is owned by the oil and gas industry contractor <a href="Saipem">Saipem S.p.A.</a>
Construction.
The vessel was designed by <a href="Gusto%20Engineering">Gusto Engineering</a> during 1984.
The vessel was built between 1985 and 1987 by Fincantieri-Cantieri Navali Italiana S.p.A. at their Monfalcone yard, <a href="Trieste">Trieste</a> in north-eastern <a href="Italy">Italy</a>. The vessel was built in two halves in a long <a href="dry%20dock">dry dock</a>. The halves were then floated out from the dry dock and mated. During the mating operation the halves were supported by temporary pontoons.
The hull mating was complete in early 1987 and the two cranes built by <a href="Reggiane">Officine Meccaniche Reggiane</a> under subcontract to <a href="American%20Hoist%20%26amp%3B%20Derrick%20Company">American Hoist & Derrick Company</a> (Amhoist) were installed in sections by the Saipem crane vessel "<a href="Castoro%20Otto">Castoro Otto</a>" in April of that year. The sea trials, which took two months, started in September, and on 15 December the vessel was handed over to Micoperi.
The cost of the vessel was not released by Micoperi but it was estimated in the technical press as being up to US$400 million.
Description.
Concept.
The "Saipem 7000", originally named the "Micoperi 7000", was conceived in the mid-1980s by its original owners <a href="Micoperi">Micoperi</a> as a multipurpose offshore oil platform installation vessel that would be able to install very large oil production platform decks (known as integrated decks) as well as the decks' supporting structures (known as jackets) using its two very large fully revolving cranes. It would also be able to support the offshore completion of the platform by providing hotel and workshop facilities for large construction crews. Saturation diving facilities would support subsea connection work. The vessel's size and semi-submersible form would allow it to operate in worse weather conditions than smaller and conventionally shaped vessels.
The huge cost of a vessel of this size would be offset by the cost and time savings made by the oil company as the large integrated decks could be completed, tested and commissioned onshore. Prior to the introduction of the large crane vessels, offshore oil platforms were made up of 1000 - 2000 tonne modules which were lifted into place individually by smaller SSCVs or monohull crane vessels and then connected together offshore, tested and then commissioned; this often took over a year. Other savings in the installation of the jackets could also be made.
Original specification.
Heavy lift.
The "Saipem 7000" has two <a href="https%3A//www.nov.com/-/media/nov/files/products/rig/marine-and-construction/offshore-cranes/lifting--handling-product-portfolio.pdf">NOV Lifting and Handling</a> <a href="https%3A//www.nov.com/products-and-services/brands/amclyde">AmClyde</a> model "Saipem 7000" fully revolving cranes. Each has a 140-metre-long boom fitted with 4 hooks. Each crane is capable of lifting up to 7,000 tonnes at 40 m lift radius using the main hook. The auxiliary hook capacities are 1st Auxiliary 2,500 tonnes at 75 m radius and 2nd Auxiliary 900 tonnes at 115 m. The whip hook has a capacity of 120 tonnes at 150 m. The 2nd Auxiliary hook can be deployed to a water depth of 450 m. The two cranes are capable of a tandem lift of 14,000 tonnes.
Each crane was fitted with engines to power the boom and load hoists, 9 tugger lines and the crane slewing system. The cranes use of wire rope of various diameters.
Ballast system.
The "Saipem 7000" was fitted with two <a href="ballast%20tank">ballast</a> systems: a conventional pumped system which could transfer up to 24,000 tonnes of water per hour using 4 <a href="pumps">pumps</a> and a free flooding system. The free flooding system used 2 m diameter <a href="valves">valves</a> to open certain compartments to the sea thus trimming or heeling the vessel. This allows the vessel to lift cargoes from barges much faster than if just the crane hoists are used.
Power system.
The vessel's main power is provided by eight 12-cylinder 8400 <a href="Horsepower">hp</a> <a href="diesel%20engine">diesel engine</a>s built by Grandi Motori Trieste, a former Fincantieri company. Later Grandi Motori was purchased by the Finnish <a href="W%C3%A4rtsil%C3%A4">Wärtsilä</a>. They provide up to 47,000 kW of electric power at 10,000 <a href="volt">V</a> 60 <a href="Hertz">Hz</a> for propulsion and positioning. Auxiliary power is provided by two 6-cylinder GMT diesel engines. There is also an emergency generator.
Total power that can be supplied is .
Mooring system.
The vessel was supplied with 16 anchor lines, 4 at each corner. Each line consists of 3350 m of 96 mm wire rope, 50 m of 92 mm <a href="chain">chain</a> and a 40-tonne Norshore Mark 3 <a href="anchor">anchor</a>. Each line has its own single drum winch. The mooring system can be used in water depths of up to 450 m.
The "Saipem 7000" is also equipped with two anchor windlasses equipped with 550m of 130mm chain and 35 tonne anchor.
Thrusters.
The vessel was fitted with 12 <a href="Azimuth%20thruster">thrusters</a>—6 on each <a href="hull%20%28watercraft%29">hull</a>. They are, per hull:
Dynamic positioning system.
The vessel is equipped with a <a href="dynamic%20positioning">dynamic positioning</a> system which uses either the thrusters or the mooring system or a combination of both, controlled by a number of computers, to hold the vessel in a predefined location.
Accommodation.
The accommodation designed for 800 people contains 30 triple <a href="cabin%20%28ship%29">cabin</a>s, 335 double cabins, 35 singles and 5 suites. The accommodation also contains a large <a href="Galley%20%28kitchen%29">galley</a> and <a href="mess">mess</a> rooms, a hospital, cinema and lounges.
1999 vessel re-fit.
During the winter of 1999/2000 the "Saipem 7000" underwent a refit to enhance its positioning and power systems and add a J-lay system.
The power system was upgraded to provide up to 70,000 kW using 12 <a href="Diesel%20engine">diesel</a> <a href="Electrical%20generator">generators</a>. To improve the vessel's resilience the generators are distributed between four separate engine rooms.
Two 5,500 kW retractable azimuthing thrusters were added, one below the forward part of each hull. The DP system control computers were also replaced.
The hull, deck and deck structures were modified to accept the Gusto designed <a href="Submarine%20pipeline">J-lay</a> tower and its support equipment. The J-lay tower can lay pipe from 4" to 32" diameter with a tension of up to 525 <a href="tonne-force">tonnes</a> (5.15 <a href="Newton%20%28unit%29">MN</a>) using the tensioners and up to 2,000 tonnes (20 MN) when using friction clamps. The deck can used to store up to 10,000 tonnes of pipe.
To allow space for the increased equipment some items from the original specification were removed, including 2 anchor winches from the bow, all the moon pools, and the boilers used to provide steam for the steam hammers.
Operations.
Early projects.
The vessel's first work was for <a href="Petrobras">Petrobras</a> the <a href="Brazil">Brazil</a>ian state oil company. The project consisted of the installation of 7 platforms in the <a href="Campos%20Basin">Campos Basin</a>. During this project the "Micoperi 7000" was also involved in the fighting of a well fire on the <a href="Enchova%20Platform">Enchova Platform</a>. The "Micoperi 7000" then proceeded to the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a> where it installed the <a href="Jolliet%20Template">Jolliet Template</a> for <a href="Conoco">Conoco</a>. In 1989 the "Micoperi 7000" arrived in the <a href="North%20Sea">North Sea</a> for the first time where it completed several projects in the <a href="Norway">Norwegian</a> sector of the North Sea. These were the <a href="Gyda%20Platform">Gyda Platform</a> for <a href="BP">BP</a>, the <a href="Togi%20Template">Togi Template</a> for <a href="Norsk%20Hydro">Norsk Hydro</a> and the <a href="Veslefrikk%20platform">Veslefrikk platform</a> for <a href="Statoil">Statoil</a>. In 1990 and 1991, the Micoperi was used in the construction and assembly of the Mossgas FA platform off the south coast of South Africa near a town called Mossel Bay.
Whilst the vessel remained busy, Micoperi were struggling financially as the low oil price prevalent in the late 1980s curtailed oil company investment. In 1991 Micoperi were forced to sell a number of their major assets including the "Micoperi 7000" to another <a href="Italy">Italian</a> contractor <a href="Saipem">Saipem</a>. Saipem took over the running of the vessel though they retained the vessel crew and the shorebased engineering support. Saipem renamed the vessel the "Saipem 7000".
The vessel continued to work, installing oil and gas production platforms, in the North Sea, Gulf of Mexico, off the Canadian east coast and the west coast of <a href="Africa">Africa</a> throughout the nineties. It was also involved in the removal of one platform, the <a href="Esso">Esso</a> Odin. During the late nineties Saipem planned an upgrade to the vessels DP system and installation of a <a href="J-Lay">J-Lay</a> system.
Projects.
The "Saipem 7000" has completed 4 J-Lay pipe projects Diana, <a href="Blue%20Stream">Blue Stream</a>, <a href="Ormen%20Lange%20%28gas%20field%29">Ormen Lange</a> and <a href="Medgaz">Medgaz</a>, but its main work continues to be heavy lift in the North Sea and the Gulf of Mexico. This includes both platform installation and removal and the addition of modules to existing platforms.
Lifting and pipelaying records.
The "Saipem 7000" set the world offshore lifting record of 12,150 tons for the Sabratha deck in the <a href="Mediterranean%20Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. A local record for the <a href="Gulf%20of%20Mexico">Gulf of Mexico</a> (Mexican area) was set with the 10,473 tons of the PB-KU-A2 deck. In July 2010, the "Saipem 7000" broke another world record by lifting the new BP Valhall Production and Hotel topside of approximately 11,600 tonnes on <a href="Dynamic%20Positioning">Dynamic Positioning</a>. The previous world record set at Sabratha was performed on the vessel's anchoring system. The first and third records were broken on 7 September 2019 when the "<a href="Sleipnir%20%28ship%2C%202019%29">Sleipnir</a>" lifted the 15,300 ton deck module for <a href="Noble%20Energy">Noble's</a> <a href="Leviathan%20gas%20field">Leviathan</a>.
The "Saipem 7000" laid the 24" pipeline for the Blue Stream project between <a href="Russia">Russia</a> and <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a> up to the record depth of 2,150 meters in the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a>. This was broken at the end of 2005 by the <a href="DCV%20Balder">Balder</a> which laid a pipeline in 2,200 meters of water, yet Balder was outbeat herself in 2014 by another laybarge of Saipem, the FDS2, which laid another 24" pipeline in 2,250 meters offshore Brazil.<a href="https%3A//www.offshore-mag.com/articles/print/volume-76/issue-10/flowlines-and-pipelines/field-development-vessel-rises-to-task-of-challenging-deepwater-project.html"></a>
